wikipedia_page.main: William Garden Blaikie FRSE (5 February 1820, in Aberdeen – 11 June 1899) was a Scottish divine, writer, biographer, and temperance reformer.

response: *Robert Rollock: First Principal of the University of Edinburgh, by William Garden Blaikie, Religious Tract Society, 1884
He was son of John Blaikie (plumber) and Helen Richardson. Married Jane Garden. Father of William Garden Blaikie and others.

In 1849, the Pilrig Model Dwellings Company was formed by the Rev. William Garden Blaikie, minister for Pilrig, to build housing for the working classes. The scheme of 44 houses in four blocks was developed by architect Patrick Wilson, and built between 1850 and 1851. Originally known as the Pilrig Model Buildings, the streets were renamed Shaw's Place, Shaw's Street and Shaw's Terrace in 1896.
* William Garden Blaikie (1820-1899), Scottish writer, biographer, and activist in the temperance movement.

Hunt was the editor of Cassell's Magazine from 1874 to 1896, and was a regular correspondent of the Musical Times. In 1886, he was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Edinburgh for his contributions to musical education. His proposers were William Garden Blaikie, John Stuart Blackie, Hugh Macmillan and William Durham. He died on 27 September 1917. He is buried with his wife, Madeline (1853-1937), in the churchyard of St John the Evangelist in Burgess Hill.

William Knight remarked on Duncan's death that "with him has perished a breathing library of wisdom." William Garden Blaikie suggested that "his profound originality, his intellectual honesty, his deep piety, and childlike simplicity, humility, and affectionateness, commanded the respect of every student."

Second of the seven recorded sons of Margaret Catherine Biggar and William Garden Blaikie, minister of Pilrig Free Church, Walter Biggar Blaikie was educated at Edinburgh Academy and the University of Edinburgh.
